name: Hoarding and Logistics
description: This chapter shows some ways to move items and fluids around. There are also some novel storage devices. Applied Energistics 2 still takes the cake for most end-game storage, but there are things to make before then, and there are some nice portable options. We also have to get into pipes. This chapter takes care of that.

quests.name: Fetch Me An Ale, Wrench!
quests.description: You will find various technical mods have their own magic tool for doing this or that. The crescent hammer from Thermal Expansion works with most of them. When it becomes time to start setting up machinery in your base, the wrench because more important than your pickaxe. When you right-click machines with this tool, it will preserve the state of the machines--often even preserving their inventory so it isn't vomited on the floor. Fluid tanks keep their fluids. Batteries keep their power. Most convenient is that one right-click will dismantle the machine, duct, pipe, conduit, or whatever you have. This is much more convenient than having to bang on them with a pick.

tasks.longDescription: You will need 3 iron ingots and 1 tin ingot to make this crescent hammer. It will never wear out, so you will have this for the rest of your game. You should look into creating a traveller's belt so you can set up a "domestic" hotbar separate from an "adventure" hotbar.

quests.name: Ducts For Items And Water
quests.description: You can use ducts to connect machines to chests, chests to chests, and machines to machines. There are ducts specifically for items and ducts specifically for fluids. They can be upgraded. Note, you don't want to pump lava through these basic fluid ducts; they'll blow up.

quests.name: Item Filtering
quests.description: Filters control items going in, and servos control items going out. This is how you can set up routing between places. Slap them on the ends of ducts and then configure them with your bare hand. You can right-click on one with that crescent hammer to take it off the pipe.

tasks.longDescription: Annoying tip: The servos don't automatically draw from connected devices. They have to be activated. You could put a lever next to one and flip it on, but that's dumb. When right-clicking on one, you will see its options. Over in the top-right is a red area you can expand to determine how it triggers from redstone signals. Disable that and it will switch to "always on."
Well, maybe you want to use a lever. I'm not your mom.

quests.name: Storing Fluids
quests.description: Sometimes you'll feel the need to move some fluids around. Specifically, lava, and probably destabilized redstone later. You can put in and take out fluids from these with a bucket, connect them with fluiducts, or put them right on top of machines that take their fluids. The seared tanks from Tinker's Construct can handle most fluids too, but only 4 buckets worth. These can handle 8. There are higher-tier ones that can handle more.

tasks.longDescription: Fun note: If you fill one of these up with lava, put it on top of a lava generator for electrical power, and then left click the bottom of it with a crescent hammer, it will automatically dump into it. It could be enough RF power for the machines you need to get to the moon. However, you'd have to be frugal, and you're probably better off... using more than two lava generators.

quests.name: A Higher-Capacity Chest
quests.description: If you want to just cram more stuff into a chest, try an iron chest. It has more slots to it. Wasn't that nice?

quests.name: Deep Storage Unit
quests.description: This is a powered device that can store ridiculous amounts of... one single item. It's a great place to stuff cobblestone, for example. Lots and lots of cobblestone. Like, billions of cobblestone.

quests.name: Back To School
quests.description: You may find that your inventory is just loaded up with random junk, and it's getting really tedious to run back to your base just to throw it all into storage. You could make a backpack. Right click on it, and it will open up a brand-new inventory into which you can shove stuff and keep going. It's made from leather. If you're short on cows or don't want to harm them, you can run some zombie flesh through a furnace to make the leather.
prerequisites: {Bear Grylls' Poop Menu}[Crawling In My Skin]

quests.name: Hardcore Plumbers
quests.description: The hardened fluiduct can withstand the extreme temperatures of lava. If you are thinking of pumping lava into your smeltery, you will want to use these. The basic copper fluiducts will disintegrate very quickly.

tasks.longDescription: These require invar, which is an alloy of 2:1 iron:nickel. You might need to dig down a little deeper to find ferrous/nickel ore. Fortunately, you don't need much of it.

quests.name: No, You Can't Sleep In It
quests.description: The knapsack is yet another way of portably storing an entire inventory's worth of stuff. The benefit of it over a backpack is that it exists in a separate inventory tab, so you don't normally have to see it. Well, that can also get annoying. It's better to use a backpack for fast storage, and a knapsack for longer-term storage. It requires making two iron tough tool rods. People usually make this thing later in the game then they could because they forget they can cast tough tool rods with a base Tinkers Construct tables.
prerequisites: {Bear Grylls' Poop Menu}[Crawling In My Skin]

tasks.longDescription: The tough rod template is confusing because the stencil is shaped different than the cast. You want to make sure you're getting the *tough* tool rod, not just a regular tool rod. If you screw up, throw the components back in the smeltery for a do-over.

You will have to cast two iron tough tool rods, which is an odd amount of iron. Think about what you use to make swords and picks, and then think about all the iron going into something you're slinging over your back. I don't get it either.

quests.name: Earning Your ... Brownish Belt
quests.description: The traveler's belt can only hold 9 items, which is coincidentally how many items you see in your hotbar. In fact, the belt lets you flip between your current hotbar and one it contains. So you can throw a bunch of junk in the toolbelt hotbar that you are normally struggling to balance in your current hotbar. Important note: You have to wear the belt through the armor screen in your inventory, and you have to use the belt toggle key to make the flip. That is mapped by default to 'B' which apparently every other mod is trying to use. I recommend going to the control configuration screen and changing it to 'V', the Alt key, or something else quick at your disposal.
prerequisites: {Bear Grylls' Poop Menu}[Crawling In My Skin]

tasks.longDescription: Pay special attention to the aluminum you need. Yes, this is a really goofy belt. You will never be the cool kid in school with this belt, but with all the swords you'll hang off of it, nobody is going to say a thing to you.

quests.name: The Golden Horde
quests.description: This little bag has the capacity of a double chest! It is a nice bag to root for if you have a bunch of resources, but no leather. This usually happens when you're running around underground too much. However, you will need a diamond, a pile of gold, and some wool. You can make wool from string, but preferably you have been farming cotton. If not, I guess you will now!

tasks.longDescription: Seriously, start handling cotton early in your game. If you are ever playing some other quest mod pack... get that cotton!

quests.name: Awww Soo Cute!!! ::^_^::
quests.description: It's just little! If you put a chest in a crafting grid, you can turn it into 9 mini chests! This is totally stupid! Actually, it's a nice thing to have when you are setting up some automated piping system for your machines, and you need a buffer, but not a huge buffer. These little guys do the job perfectly.

tasks.longDescription: Throw a chest in a crafting grid. End of story. If you hate it, put all 9 of the mini chests back in the grid and get your chest back.

quests.name: Getting Drawered In
quests.description: The Storage Drawers mod is new for Minecraft 1.7.10. Applied Energistics is still well-regarded as the ultimate storage solution, but storage drawers gives you something you can use very early in the game. Instead of poring through piles of chests, you can slap all your items on the wall in drawers, and pull/push them through right and left clicks. You can get pretty fast with this once you get the hang of them. This requires a ton of wood, but you should be able to acquire that easily.

tasks.longDescription: The 1x1 drawer seems kind of stupid, but it makes for a nice hole for throwing in the base stone you are mining (cobblestone, limestone, marble, granite, blablabla). This slaps it up on a wall where you can pull/push it quickly.

A 2x2 lets you slap 4 things in one block. By the way, I come from a part of the US where they pronounce "drawer" as "draw." My mother still does it, and it makes my wife squeal because she loves regional accents.

quests.name: Compacting Drawers
quests.description: These are a good place to stuff refined metals. They can go in as blocks, ingots, or nuggets, and it will just internally cram them into blocks. This gives you a lot of space.

tasks.longDescription: Just make one, and I'll give you some more.

quests.name: Controlling Drawers
quests.description: The drawer controller serves as a giant mouth for pulling crap out of your inventory and into your storage drawers. Later, when you set up Applied Energistics 2, you can slap a storage bus on it, and make your storage drawer inventory available to your ME network. This is a smart thing to make in the long term.

tasks.longDescription: It does require a diamond. Apparently, it works in a 12x12 area. What you want to do is arrange your drawers on a wall and shove the controller on the ground somewhere in the middle of the wall. If you double-right-click it, it will suck up all the non-tool stuff in your inventory it can and add it to your drawers in one swoop.

quests.name: Increasing Drawer Space
quests.description: There are various tiers of upgrades your can apply to your drawers. Some let you know if they are full. Others increase space. The obsidian-level upgrade should be pretty easy to make if you have been following the hell tutorials. Use these to boost space in some of the drawers where you've been having space problems.

tasks.longDescription: If you want to do this a lot, and lava is becoming a problem, look up the lava fabricator to make lava quickly.

quests.name: No Bag Ban Here!
quests.description: I live in a city that banned plastic bags, which makes the MFR plastic bags pretty funny. I feel kind of dirty using them. These things can only hold a few stacks of items, but they are so easy to make. They require plastic, but not leather or wool. They are a great way to prolong finding your final base by letting you pack up all your junk as you wander the country-side like a bag lady.

tasks.longDescription: They do require string though. Hey, how about farming some cotton! I will throw in some explosives so you can carve out your next base with less fuss!

quests.name: Nice Rack! Oh, nice shelf too
quests.description: There are a few things that should get dedicated storage. You should have a tool rack near the door to your base. You put your weapons and "outside tools" in there. When you go outside, you put your wrenches and base tools in that rack and take out all the outside tools. A bookshelf organizes all the manuals, guides, and whatnot you accumulate playing other quest packs. A shelf for potions is also nice if you horde that kind of stuff.

tasks.longDescription: Each tool rack can hold four tools. I generally need three racks to hold all the random stuff I get when playing for real.
Yeah, you can throw all your books in a chest, but you have conditioned yourself your whole life to look for books in a bookcase, so make one that you'll put somewhere accessible.
One of these should last you for a long time . . . until you build a mob grinder.

quests.name: Not Just For Smoking Meat
quests.description: Extra Utilities provides drums for storing fluids. Fluids can be automatically inserted/removed from drums from the top and bottom. You can use a bucket on them instead if that is your thing. The big deal is that one drum can store 256 buckets worth of one liquid. Remember to use a wrench to move them!

tasks.longDescription: It does take a lot of iron, but you are probably swimming in iron by this point.

quests.name: Only The Strongest Survive
quests.description: If you wrap up a chest in 4 tin, you can make a strongbox. For this, you get a chest that has... less capacity than the original one. What?! Well, if you fill it up and bust it with a pick, it will keep its contents! It is not as nice as a backpack since you have to pop it back down to use it, but chances are that you'll have the chest and then tin before the leather or cloth.

tasks.longDescription: Just surround a chest with a tin ingot on each side in a crafting grid.

quests.name: Box Of Enchantment
quests.description: Here's a fun one. You can enchant these strongboxes! Maybe you've run into the enchantment table. Maybe not. We haven't really mentioned it because vanilla enchanting is a lottery of suck. You get to pick one of three enchantments without knowing what they will be. However, a strongbox can only take one enchantment: holding. It doesn't matter what gibberish option you pick for it then, so pick the cheapest.

tasks.longDescription: Well I guess you need an enchantment table. This is annoying to make, but you might as well as somewhere in your adventures, you need to give something somewhere one of these as a crafting ingredient. You will need some obsidian, two diamonds, and a book.

Slap the strongbox in the enchantment table, and just pick which ever one is the cheapest enchantment. It will sap from your experience bar, but you should have more than enough to do it by now, just from gathering coal and charcoal. To have the quest detect it correctly, empty out the box first. Oh, and use the original strongbox, not the cool resonant one I gave you. Your reward are essence berries which can be eaten to restore the XP you spent making this thing. THEN you can enchant the resonant strongbox too! Muahaha!

quests.name: Yatta!
quests.description: If you haven't figured out by now, this modpack has lots of pipes, tubes, ducts, and whatnot. EnderIO is part of that mix. People have started to favor these conduits in particular because item, fluid, and power conduits can be overlapped in one block! This makes them generally cleaner to use in tight spaces. Of course, it has to start with *another* wrench.

tasks.longDescription: The yeta wrench manipulates Ender IO conduits and equipment. Other wrenches kind of work too, but the yeta will do the best job with some of the fiddly bits. Hey, when you overlap conduits in one space, you have to expect some fine print...

quests.name: Doing The Long Con
quests.description: Here's EnderIO's item conduit. It will transport items here and there. It doesn't need servos and filters to manage behavior at the places it is connected, although you need filter upgrades if you want to be picky about what moves where.

tasks.longDescription: I don't know why, but I hate making the conduit binder. It's much cheaper than other mods' stuff, but I'm just not thinking of clay, gravel, and sand when I'm making pipes. But, well, here you go. You need this as a pretty common base for EnderIO stuff.

You also need some pulsating iron. Fortunately, you don't need much. It is still a fussy thing to have early in the game. Well, what did you expect from a mod named "Ender IO?" This mod gobbles up ender pearls. But you can't complain because I know if you made it here, I already gave you one! You can make this alloy using an induction furnace, or Ender IO's own alloy furnace.

Put it all together and get yourself some item conduits! For all the effort, you at least don't need to also create filters and servos like you need from Thermal Dynamics. You right-click where these conduits run into stuff, and you can specify which way the go and what they do. Make sure that redstone control is off; usually that's what you want. Also, make sure they are set to the right mode (insert/extract).

quests.name: Filtering Out The Garbage
quests.description: The time will come with Ender IO where you will want item conduits to filter specific things to specific devices. This will end up using up quite a bit of resources for what it needs to do. You need some paper, a chest, and some iron. You will be making a hopper and wrapping it in paper. For your troubles, you get something you can put in the GUI of the item conduits to have them filter for this or that thing.

quests.name: Poking Around
quests.description: The conduit probe is a nice little toy for checking what is happening inside your pipes. Truth be told, more complicated routing should be handled by an AE2 ME network, but this can help you diagnose if something is screwed up. However, it also has a mode for copying settings from one source/destination to another.

tasks.longDescription: Electrical steel is a particularly goofy requirement for this. You can make alloys at this point, so you should be able to roll out some steel. So bind it to some silicon, which you can make from burning sand. You also need a redstone alloy, made by burning some redstone with silicon. There's a lot of heat going on around here!

There are some other crafting steps to make this probe, but you should have the hard stuff out of the way now--except maybe for getting a little bit of nether quartz. After that, you can make the probe!

quests.name: RF Chameleon
quests.description: Mekanism has these Universal Cables that are aware of how to transfer power across a large variety of mods. A lot more mods have been standardizing on redstone flux, so this has become less of a problem. Even without that, they transmit pretty well! The base cables can transfer over 1,000 RF/tick, and they're pretty simple to make. The next step up are also pretty easy to make and transmit over 5,000 RF/tick.

tasks.longDescription: Two steel and some redstone dust. It's almost refreshing compared to what it takes to make some of these other cables!

quests.name: Fluctuating Heart
quests.description: The fluctuating itemduct is actually a really good duct, but it wasn't well publicized in the transition from Thermal Expansion in 1.6.4 to Thermal Dynamics in 1.7.10. For the cost of an itemduct, and a bit of redstone, you can make a duct that performs better than a hardened fluxduct--transmitting 2,000RF/tick. It also can carry items! The trick is cramming destabilized redstone into the device, using a magma crucible and a fluid transposer.

tasks.longDescription: The magma crucible is a non-trivial machine to craft, but it's great for busting down redstone into destabilized redstone. You might have already made this machine because it comes up in the book in a few places. I'll only check if you have one. You feed it redstone, and it will turn it into a fluid. You can place the fluid transposer alongside the magma crucible. This lets you transmit fluid from the crucible to the transposer without any special fluid connectors.
Stuff 200mb of destabilized redstone into an opaque itemduct, and you'll get a fluctuating itemduct. Use two pieces of redstone to get 200mb.

quests.name: Are We Transceiving?
quests.description: This is EnderIO's version of a tesseract. This is almost easier to make, except for needing an enderman's head. If you need some help with that, look at the "Leave It To Cleaver" quest in the Tools and Toys chapter. You also need some ender pearls. That being said, you get something that is technically a little bit more versatile than a tesseract because it has built-in filters. What's a tesseract? Oh, I got ahead of myself. That lets you send items, fluids, and powers across huge distances and multiple dimensions. For multiple dimensions, you probably want a chunkloader, by the way. See the Philadephia Experiment chapter for that one.

tasks.longDescription: You'll need to make vibrant alloys, which eat up some ender pearls. Not many... about four. If you are investing into this, then you want to get an endermen farm going, or have a nice vein of Ender Ore to harvest.
Yeah... this machine does creative surgery with heads. You can use it to re-purpose zombie heads, but we're using it on an enderman head here. Yeah...
If you get this far, then you must have been able to splice an enderman head. Good for you!

quests.name: Are You Dense?
quests.description: Dense and vacuum itemducts fool the duct network into thinking things are much closer or much further away than they actually are. They are useful for assigning priority to different areas of a duct. A good example for using these are in a tree farm. You probably want a dense itemduct heading to a trash can to take care of overflow, but it shouldn't trigger unless there is overflow. You might combust saplings from the tree farm, but you only want to do that if the planter has enough saplings to sustain the farm. So you put a vacuum duct on the path to the planter. The planter will then get saplings until it is full since its priority is more important.

tasks.longDescription: Craft a regular itemduct with some pulverized lead, and you'll get a dense itemduct. This will act like 1,000 itemducts in terms of distance. So if you have two segments with dense itemducts, they will be prioritized by which one has the longest real path. If that's not what you want, add one more dense itemduct on the one you want to have the lowest priority.

Throw some pulverized silver on the duct, and it becomes a vacuum itemduct. I don't have the specifics of how this duct functions. I think it basically subtracts 1000 to the distance, the the network just uses the lowest score. In this case, negative numbers are lower, so the path with the vacuum duct will win out. It might be more subtle, but that's how it tends to go for me.

quests.name: A Pet Purple Retriever
quests.description: Retrievers are a new thing brought by Thermal Dynamics when that all was created for Minecraft 1.7.10. They introduce a very peculiar filtering system. At their most basic, you can use it instead of a servo/filter combination. Put it on the destination, give it something to look for, and it will draw those items from any inventories attached to any item ducts in the whole network, so long as the destination has room for it. So they can be particularly useful if you do not want to overload the pipes with dumped items, or you have multiple places to look and don't want to deal with all the servos.

tasks.longDescription: Making one of these is a huge pain. That's the downside. You need an Eye of Ender. :( That's an ender pearl crossed with blaze powder.
Retriever time! This is the easy part. It's an easy recipe after you get that Eye of Ender.

quests.name: Mechanically Speaking
quests.description: Mechanical pipes are particularly useful for transferring fluids, even though they can also do items. They fill a nice niche for Big Reactors' turbines--particularly the advanced ones. The base one can do steam at 100mb/tick without worrying about hot fluids melting them down like if you transfer lava. The next tier is 400mb/tick, which is generally superior to other fluid pipes in its class.

tasks.longDescription: I'll give you 16 advanced mechanical pipes if you can make the base one.

quests.name: Conducive To Irony
quests.description: This is Ender IO's base power transmitting conduit. This transmits at 640 RF/tick, which is much better than the 200 RF/tick of Thermal Dynamics' leadstone fluxduct. However, it requires making an alloy that needs either an alloy smelter or an induction smelter.

tasks.longDescription: So let's rewind from all this metal and stuff, and make a little bit of conduit binder from sand, gravel, and clay. I always miss this because I'm always thinking, "Metal, metal, metal." Maybe you'll get better at it than me.

You need three ingots of this conductive alloy. Each ingot is made by smelter an iron ingot with a redstone dust. You need a Thermal Expansion induction smelter or an Ender IO alloy smelter for this. The former takes less of more advanced materials, and the latter requires more of less advanced materials. You might be wondering how people do these machines without power cables. Well, they just cram the machines against their generators!
A stripe of binder, a stripe of alloy, and another stripe of binder. Bam.
